article_title: After court victory, gay vote likely to meld into mainstream
article_text:
After court victory, gay vote likely to meld into mainstream

Photo: Josh Edelson, Bloomberg Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks during a news conference outside City...

It’s clear that Democrats have gained the advantage on the issue of same-sex marriage. The question is: Will the celebration last long enough that the LGBT community remembers to vote for us?

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Willie Brown
article_metadata.description: After court victory, gay vote likely to meld into mainstream  Will the celebration last long enough that the LGBT community remembers to vote for us?  [...] after Friday’s U.S. Supreme Court decision legalizing same-sex marriages nationwide, the gay vote will probably meld into the mainstream, and the LGBT community will more closely resemble the rest of the electorate: concerned with such issues as the economy and education.  [...] will that tide still be lifting Gavin’s boat when he runs for governor?  The dinner reception at City Hall was to die for.  [...] Mayor Ed Lee showed off the Giants’ three championship trophies, followed by the 49ers’ five pieces of Super Bowl hardware, followed by the America’s Cup.  [...] Lee called up San Jose Mayor Sam Liccardo and Oakland’s Libby Schaaf to bring out the Warriors’ NBA trophy.  [...] to win all those trophies we had to beat teams in cities represented by half the mayors in the room.  Everyone is suddenly fixated on the Confederate flag, but we’re in danger of missing the larger picture:  In his last 18 months in office, President Obama has a golden opportunity to become a spokesman against racism.  Black people have long wanted Obama to make sure race receives the same attention and priority as does Asian trade policy, as does that Iranian nuclear deal, as does Obamacare.  SFMOMA’s cover may be a museum, but the new digs will have much more, including a good-size auditorium, a restaurant twice the size of the old one and two stores.  Not to take anything away from Golden State Warriors President Rick Welts, the grand marshal of Sunday’s Pride Parade, but Caitlyn Jenner would have been my pick.
article_metadata.author.name: By Willie Brown

[...] after Friday’s U.S. Supreme Court decision legalizing same-sex marriages nationwide, the gay vote will probably meld into the mainstream, and the LGBT community will more closely resemble the rest of the electorate: concerned with such issues as the economy and education.  [...] will that tide still be lifting Gavin’s boat when he runs for governor?  The dinner reception at City Hall was to die for.  [...] Mayor Ed Lee showed off the Giants’ three championship trophies, followed by the 49ers’ five pieces of Super Bowl hardware, followed by the America’s Cup. [...] to win all those trophies we had to beat teams in cities represented by half the mayors in the room.  Everyone is suddenly fixated on the Confederate flag, but we’re in danger of missing the larger picture:  In his last 18 months in office, President Obama has a golden opportunity to become a spokesman against racism.  Black people have long wanted Obama to make sure race receives the same attention and priority as does Asian trade policy, as does that Iranian nuclear deal, as does Obamacare.  SFMOMA’s cover may be a museum, but the new digs will have much more, including a good-size auditorium, a restaurant twice the size of the old one and two stores.  Not to take anything away from Golden State Warriors President Rick Welts, the grand marshal of Sunday’s Pride Parade, but Caitlyn Jenner would have been my pick.
